table-wrap.anchoringText: In 2014, there were minimal changes made to the completion frac design. Table 1 shows the typical frac design parameters. The most notable change was the reduction from 75% of stage fluid volume consisting of linear gel-based frac fluid to only 15% of stage fluid volume being linear gel-based. This change not only resulted in reduced frac water usage and lower completion costs, but it also increased the operator's ability to fracture numerous intervals that were too difficult to frac using the previous design.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Fracturing Design Parameters for Sections I, II & III

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fracturing Design Parameters for Sections I, II & III

table-wrap.anchoringText: Concentrations of the water tracers recovered show the two Wasatch intervals contributed a combined 34.1% of the total tracer ppb recovered from all stages during the sampling period. Nevertheless, it is worth noting the upward trend illustrated in Table 2, Well A CFT Diagnostic Table, for the Green River III and V formations, stages 7 and 8, respectively. These two stages amount to 50.5% of the total tracer ppb for the last sample.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Well A CFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Well A's oil contribution profile, as exhibited by the OFT recovery results in Table 3, reveals that stage 6, completed over intervals of the Green River V and VI, as well as stage 4, completed in the Green River VIII, had higher than expected oil contributions of 22.2% and 21.7% of the total tracer ppb, respectively. Furthermore, the lower Green River VI as well as the lower Green River VIII and the Wasatch intervals, stimulated in frac stages 5 and 1-3, respectively, generated the lowest oil contributions.
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: Well A OFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Load fluid flowback recovery of water tracers shows an even flow profile early in the sampling period. However, after about ten days, the deeper stages completed in the Wasatch and Green River VIII started unloading at a noticeably higher rate. By the end of the sampling period, these stages accounted for 44%of the total ppb recorded. Table 4 shows the normalized concentrations (ppb) for each water sample taken from this well.
table-wrap.label: Table 4
table-wrap.caption: Well B CFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Well B's oil contribution profile, represented by the OFT recovery results in Table 5, reveals the Green River III, the upper Green River V and the Green River VIII members of the Green River formation as the leading sources of oil for the well with 24.1%, 22.2% and 17.8% of the total tracer ppb, respectively. In addition, the only completed Wasatch segment and the Green River VI segment sequentially achieved the lowest oil contribution.
table-wrap.label: Table 5
table-wrap.caption: Well B OFT Diagnostic Table.

table-wrap.anchoringText: In Well C, the load fluid flowback recovery indicates that the lower four stages, covering the Wasatch, and Green River V and VI, accounted for a combined 72.8% of the total tracer ppb with 38.4%, 24.3% and 10.1%, respectively, thus displaying a deeper dominated flowback profile throughout the sampling period, as is clearly represented by the degrading color scale in Table 6.
table-wrap.label: Table 6
table-wrap.caption: Well C CFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Well C's oil contribution profile, indicated by the OFT recovery results in Table 7, reveals that the three Green River V intervals, frac stages 4â€“6, as the foremost sources of contributed oil for the well with a combined 42.4% contribution of the total tracer ppb. Additionally, the Green River VI and Green 1, 2 and 3, completed with frac stages 3 and 8, respectively, shows the poorest oil contributions with around 6% each.
table-wrap.label: Table 7
table-wrap.caption: Well C OFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Load fluid flowback recovery shows an even flowback profile from all three of the traced stages in the Wasatch throughout the sampling period, which was stopped after 30 days to resume completion of the upper stages. Table 8 shows the normalized concentrations for all the water samples analyzed.
table-wrap.label: Table 8
table-wrap.caption: Well D CFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Well D's oil contribution profile is shown in Table 9, and is dominated by the uppermost interval of the Wasatch formation with 62.9% of the total tracer ppb, followed by the lowest Wasatch interval with 21.2%and, finally, a lagging middle interval with only 15.8%.
table-wrap.label: Table 9
table-wrap.caption: Well D OFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Concentrations of the water tracers recovered show the two Wasatch intervals completed with stages 1 and 2 contributed a combined 34.5% of the total tracer ppb. In addition, stage 7 completed over the Green 3 and 4 formations returned another 30.5% of the total tracer ppb and 35.5% of the total tracer ppb for the last sample. Table 10 shows the normalized concentrations for all the water samples analyzed.
table-wrap.label: Table 10
table-wrap.caption: Well E CFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Well E's oil contribution profile is shown in Table 11, and reveals that the Green River III and Green 3 and 4 formations had higher than normal oil contributions at 18.6% and 19.3% of the total tracer ppb, respectively. Furthermore, the lower segment of the Wasatch and the Green River IV and V formations stimulated in frac stages 1 and 4, respectively, exhibits the poorest oil contributions.
table-wrap.label: Table 11
table-wrap.caption: Well E OFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: The only other substantial contributor was the Green 3 at 15.9%, but that is significantly less than the Wasatch intervalsâ€™ 53.3%. Fig. 7 illustrates the percent deviation from an equitable CFT contribution for each stage, while Table 12 shows the normalized concentrations for all of the water samples analyzed.
table-wrap.label: Table 12
table-wrap.caption: WELL F CFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Well F's oil contribution profile, as shown in Table 13, exhibits the Green 3, Green River III, and Upper Green River VI formations as the leading sources of oil for the well with 18.7%, 16.9% and 14.6% of the total tracer ppb, respectively. In addition, the lower segments of the Wasatch and Green River VI sequentially achieved the lowest oil contributions.
table-wrap.label: Table 13
table-wrap.caption: WELL F OFT Diagnostic Table.

table-wrap.anchoringText: Load fluid flowback recovery shows an even flowback profile across all stages except for stage 6 of the Green 1 and 2 intervals, which initially recovered at least twice as much frac fluid as any of the other stages. Over the entire sampling period, the Green 1â€“5 intervals were found to be the main water source, dominating the load fluid flowback with 54.1% of the total tracer ppb recovered. Table 14 shows the normalized concentrations for all the water samples analyzed.
table-wrap.label: Table 14
table-wrap.caption: WELL G CFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Well G's oil contribution profile, as shown in Table 15, exhibits the Green River III and Green 3 and 4 intervals as the foremost sources of oil for the well with 19.7% and 15.8% of the total tracer ppb, respectively. Additionally, the Green River IV and V, and Green 1 and 2, completed in frac stages 4 and 6, respectively, had the poorest oil contributions.
table-wrap.label: Table 15
table-wrap.caption: WELL G OFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Well H was uniquely traced as the frac fluids were split into two halves, and each half was traced with a different CFT. The two Wasatch intervalsâ€™ stimulated flowback concentrations totaled 34.1% of the total tracer ppb and it is only surpassed by the Green 3 interval with 36.4% of the total tracer ppb, proving those intervals to again be the main sources of water in section 17. Table 16 shows the normalized concentrations for all of the water samples analyzed.
table-wrap.label: Table 16
table-wrap.caption: WELL H CFT Diagnostic Table

table-wrap.anchoringText: Well H's oil contribution profile is dominated by the Green 3 formation with 41.6% of the total tracer ppb, as shown in Table 17, followed by the two Wasatch intervals with 25.4%. Lagging behind is the Green River VI formation with a âˆ’54.1% deviation from an equitable contribution, as illustrated in Fig. 8, which also shows the percent deviation from an equitable oil contribution for each of the formations.
table-wrap.label: Table 17
table-wrap.caption: WELL H OFT Diagnostic Table
